talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, in writing, on 14 February 2005:

item.para: In respect of the anti-finning regulations in the Northern Territory Joint Authority Shark Fishery, how and where are the shark trunks being landed at the Port of Darwin being disposed of.
What records are available in respect of shark trunk disposal.
How is compliance with the anti-finning regulations being determined.
To what extent are shark trunks still being discarded at sea.
What is the level of compliance investment and presence in the Northern Territory Shark Fishery.
What level of training in fisheries compliance is given to the compliance officers and can he confirm that the compliance officers are members of the Northern Territory police force.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr Truss

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Shark trunks are being sold to local, national and international markets. Product uses include fresh and frozen fillets for human consumption, fish emulsion and they are internationally processed into seafood balls, tempura and soups for human consumption.

All shark product weights and cuts are recorded by fishers in monthly market logbooks at the point of sale and comparisons are made with logbook returns from Traders/Processors to validate monthly returns from individual fishers.

Random on board vessel inspections are made by Northern Territory Fisheries Police officers to ensure compliance with gear and fin ratio regulations. The Fisheries Group of the Northern Territory Department of Business, Industry and Resource Development also holds annual fin ratio review workshops with industry and compulsory logbook returns are analysed regularly.

Shark trunks are not being dumped at sea. Fishers are required to land a prescribed amount of meat with every fin landed (fin ratios). In addition, recent licence conditions prevent shark meat from leaving port again on board a vessel.

There are 17 dedicated Fisheries Police members in the Police Marine Enforcement Section of the Northern Territory Police Force. In 2004, 47 random compliance checks were made on vessels operating in the Northern Territory shark fishery.
Officers of the dedicated marine police section are fully trained and endorsed Northern Territory Police officers.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 14 February 2005:

item.para: How many asylum seekers from tsunami affected countries are (a) being held in detention; and (b) on temporary protection visas (TPVs).
Will the Government urgently review the applications for permanent protection for those asylum seekers from tsunami affected countries.

Has the Minister’s department been approached by any asylum seekers from tsunami affected countries requesting assistance relating to the welfare of their families in tsunami affected areas; if so, (a) how many; and (b) is the Minister able to assist those families; if so, how.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Departmental systems indicate that, as at 11 February 2005, there was one protection visa applicant from a tsunami affected country who was in detention. This person’s application was recently remitted to the Department by the Refugee Review Tribunal. Further checks are being undertaken in order to decide the visa application.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Departmental systems indicate that as at 11 February 2005, there were some 90 remaining temporary protection visa holders from tsunami affected countries.

Applications for further protection visas lodged by temporary protection visa holders from tsunami affected countries are being assessed on their merits under the normal arrangements for determining applications for further protection visas. To be eligible for grant of a further protection visa, an applicant must either be found to be owed protection obligations under the Refugees Convention or be accompanying a family member who has been found to be owed such protection obligations. The tsunami and the damage and disruption it has caused do not meet the grounds set out in the Refugees Convention for identifying persons owed refugee protection. However, where the Refugee Review Tribunal affirms a decision to refuse a further protection visa, the Minister has a non-compellable personal power to substitute for the Tribunal decision a decision which is more favourable to the applicant, where the Minister considers this to be in the public interest.

(3) (a) An emergency Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) hotline commenced operating from 30 December 2004 to provide advice on visa arrangements for Australian citizens and residents with relatives in tsunami-affected areas and foreign nationals from affected areas temporarily in Australia.

As at 9 February 2005, some 900 calls had been received by DIMIA from persons seeking advice on visa arrangements for Australian citizens and residents with relatives in tsunami-affected areas and foreign nationals from affected areas temporarily in Australia.
The hotline was discontinued on 18 February 2005 due to the diminishing number of calls. DIMIA’s website has been upgraded to provide a link to information related to tsunami affected countries.

item.label: (a)
item.para: An emergency Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) hotline commenced operating from 30 December 2004 to provide advice on visa arrangements for Australian citizens and residents with relatives in tsunami-affected areas and foreign nationals from affected areas temporarily in Australia.

As at 9 February 2005, some 900 calls had been received by DIMIA from persons seeking advice on visa arrangements for Australian citizens and residents with relatives in tsunami-affected areas and foreign nationals from affected areas temporarily in Australia.
The hotline was discontinued on 18 February 2005 due to the diminishing number of calls. DIMIA’s website has been upgraded to provide a link to information related to tsunami affected countries.

item.label: (b)
item.para: My Department is maintaining communication with relevant migrant communities in Australia, including monitoring the needs of those whose relatives are missing or have been killed or injured.

Concerns by immigration detainees about the welfare of family members in affected areas have been addressed by providing access to overseas phones calls and through tracing assistance from the Australian Red Cross. It is not possible to identify the extent to which the calls were from asylum seekers from tsunami affected countries requesting assistance relating to the welfare of their families in tsunami affected areas.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 16 February 2005:

item.para: Can he confirm the report in The Age on 28 January which stated that a person accompanied by three security guards on a Thai Airlines flight had been chained by the hands and feet and had gaffer tape around his head covering his mouth; if so, were these actions taken by the Australia Government and, if they were, why.
How was this passenger able to eat, drink or go to the toilet.
Have there been other instances of people being transported under similar conditions; if so, how many.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

quote.para: I am advised that:

item.para: The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) was responsible for the removal of this person as he had no entitlement to remain in Australia.

In exceptional circumstances the use of restraint on high risk removees during a removal operation may be required. This includes cases where the removee presents a high security risk or behaves in a way that threatens the safety of themself or others.

In this case, the removee was violent, noisy and disruptive during the removal process. He assaulted the escorts and attempted to bite them. He also bit his own lips, apparently in an attempt to delay his removal and appear unfit to travel. The escorting officers found that it was necessary to restrain the person with hand restraints, leg restraints and mouth tape, to allow him to board the flight without posing further danger to himself or others.

The removee was restrained for the minimum time required. The flight departed Sydney with a stopover in Melbourne. The restraints were removed when the flight departed Melbourne on its international leg. The removee was allowed to eat and drink. He was also allowed toilet breaks.

During the period July 2003 – June 2004 there were 10 reported incidents of removees being restrained with hand and leg restraints. In addition, five were restrained by the hands only. During the period July 2004 – February 2005 there were 11 reported incidents of removees restrained with hand and leg restraints. Four of these 11 removees were additionally restrained with mouth tape. In once instance it was also necessary to tape a removee’s finger nails due to attempts in the past to use them as an instrument to harm himself and others.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 16 February 2005:

item.para: Has the Minister read the article titled ‘When the journalist is a party spin doctor, it’s bad PR for real news’ in the Sydney Morning Herald on 15 February 2005.

In respect of those parts of the report that say “In shades of Australia’s cash‑for‑comment scandal, a conservative syndicated US columnist and pundit has been secretly contracted for $307,000 by the Bush Administration to promote the President’s education policies in his columns and TV appearances” and “it is no longer clear who is and who isn’t a journalist in the US”, can the Minister guarantee that the Australian Government has not entered into any similar agreement with a journalist or commentator in Australia; if not, why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Yes.
My Portfolio does not have a whole of Government responsibility for this issue.

Disclosure of commercial arrangements between radio current affairs presenters and sponsors is provided for by the Broadcasting Services (Commercial Radio Current Affairs Disclosure) Standard 2000. The standard requires on-air disclosure during current affairs programs of commercial agreements between sponsors and presenters that have the potential to affect the content of those programs. Commercial radio licensees are also required to provide the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) with particulars of each commercial agreement between sponsors and presenters of current affairs programs or their associates. This register is published on the website of the ABA. Licensees are also required to publish these details on any website operated by or on behalf of the licensee. Compliance with the Standard is a condition of a broadcaster’s licence.

The Commercial Television Industry Code of Practice also provides for the disclosure of commercial arrangements. The Code requires the disclosure, by licensees, of any agreements or arrangements under which a licensee, an independent producer or a presenter agrees with a third party to endorse or feature the third party’s products or services in a factual program in exchange for consideration. The disclosure must be made either during the program or in the credits of the program and should adequately bring the existence of any such commercial arrangement to the attention of viewers in a way that is readily understandable to a reasonable person.

It should be noted that my Portfolio responsibilities for media issues in Australia do not include the operation of the print media. Any concerns the honourable member may have regarding the impact of commercial agreements on the representation of news and current affairs in the print media should be directed to the Australian Press Council (APC).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 17 February 2005:

item.para: In respect of the findings of the W.A. Medical Board of Inquiry against Dr McKenzie, did Dr McKenzie pay the fine of $10,000 imposed on him or was it paid by Defence.
Did the W.A. Board order Dr McKenzie to pay 75% of the Board’s legal costs; if so, (a) what was that sum and (b) what proportion of that sum was paid by Defence.
Did the legal firm, Phillips Fox, bill Defence for 1,178.5 hours of its services in defending Dr McKenzie; if so, what was that sum.
Is the Minister able to say what costs were incurred by the female officer who was the victim in this case.
Has Defence met any of the costs incurred by the victim in this case; if so, what sum; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Defence did not pay the fine.
Yes. (a) $75,000. (b) 80 per cent of the amount payable by Dr McKenzie.

Defence was billed for 1,178.6 hours (the previous figure of 1,178.5 hours stated by Defence was a typographical error). The sum was $377,221.28 for legal costs, including Counsel’s fees, for representing Dr McKenzie.
No.
No. The requests for assistance made by that person have not been considered to be within the assistance provisions set out in the Attorney-General’s Legal Services Directions.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 17 February 2005:

item.para: Does the Government intend to proceed with the purchase of the F-35; if so, (a) when will the first F-35s arrive and (b) how many will arrive in the first delivery.
Will the F-35s be delivered progressively over the two-year period or will they all arrive together at some point within the two-year period.
When is it planned to withdraw the F-111s from service.
When is it planned to withdraw the F/A-18 Hornets from service.
What contingency plans have been made in case the delivery of the F-35 is delayed.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: The Government has not yet made a formal decision to purchase the Joint Strike Fighter.
Presuming a decision to acquire the aircraft, delivery for the first two phases of Air 6000 (Phases 2A/B) is expected to occur over about a five-year period from 2012.
Around 2010.

The nominal withdrawal date for the F/A-18 Hornet is 2015. The eventual withdrawal date of the last F/A-18s will be determined in conjunction with determining the optimum delivery profile of the Joint Strike Fighter.
The structural life of the F/A-18 is being extended as part of the Hornet Upgrade Program.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 17 February 2005:

item.para: In respect of the compensation to be paid to those affected by the F-111 Deseal/Reseal process, how is the value of compensation for each applicant to be determined.
When will each of the applicants be advised of the procedure of applying for compensation.
When will compensation be paid.
Is the payment to each applicant contingent on no further legal action being taken on the part of the applicant.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, in writing, on 7 March 2005:

item.para: In respect of the vessel Capitaine Tasman (IMO Number 9210725), (a) has it ever operated in Australian waters under a single or continuous voyage permit; if so, when, (b) does it operate a regular service through Australian ports, (c) does it have an approved security plan which complies with the International Ship and Port Facility Code (ISPS), (d) has the Office of Transport Security ever had any concerns in relation to the security of this vessel, and (e) has it ever been boarded and inspected by the (i) Office of Transport Security and (ii) AMSA officials; if so, when.
Was the Office of Transport Security aware that the crew of this vessel was denied access to shore leave when the ship arrived in Australia on 17 February 2005.
Can he confirm that the denial of shore leave for the crew of this vessel was a breach of Australia’s obligations under the ISPS.
Was the denial of shore leave in any way related to security concerns in respect of (a) the vessel and (b) any of the crew.
Is the Office of Transport Security aware of any current security alerts regarding the ISPS for ports in Fiji.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr Anderson

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: My Department’s records indicate that coasting trade permits were held by the Capitaine Tasman in the period July 2000 to June 2001.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Published information indicates that the Capitaine Tasman is part of a regular liner cargo shipping service through Australian ports.

item.label: (c)
item.para: According to the available records the vessel has a current International Ship Security Certificate and therefore would have a ship security plan registered with its Flag state.

item.label: (d)
item.para: The OTS Operations Centre has security compliance assessed this vessel on nine occasions; 04.7.2004, 26.7.2004, 31.8.2004, 17.9.2004, 06.12.2004, 3.11.2004, 06.1.2005, 14.2.2005, 15.3.2005. The assessments raised no security concerns.
(e) (i) The OTS Operations Centre has not issued any Maritime Security Tasking Requests to inspect this vessel.

item.label: (e) (i)
item.para: The OTS Operations Centre has not issued any Maritime Security Tasking Requests to inspect this vessel.

On 17.2.2005, the OTS’s Operations Centre received a call from an Australian representative from the International Transport Federation. The caller was querying as to why crew had been restricted on board the vessel on 16.2.2005 at the port of Brisbane.

The ISPS Code provides that security plans must address procedures for facilitating shore leave for ships’ personnel. It does not guarantee it. All security plans approved by the Australian Government meet this requirement of the ISPS Code.
(4) (a) No. (b) The denial of shore leave was a decision made by DIMIA under the Migration Act.

item.label: (4) (a)
item.para: No. (b) The denial of shore leave was a decision made by DIMIA under the Migration Act.
OTS is not aware of any current security alerts regarding the ISPS Code for Fijian ports.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 7 March 2005:

item.para: When did the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) first form the view that an additional wide-coverage community radio service should be made available in Sydney.
When did the ABA decide to make the 1386 AM radio frequency available in Sydney for a community broadcasting service instead of a narrowcasting service.

Why did the ABA (a) reject all eight applications for the 1386 AM radio frequency in Sydney in March 2003, (b) deny the grant of a temporary radio licence, and (c) call for another round of public comment on or about 22 April 2004.
What is the current status of the granting of a radio licence for the 1386 AM frequency.
Will a licence for the 1386 AM frequency be granted; if so, when; if not, why not.

Can the Minister confirm that Sydney Christian Broadcasters Ltd, known as Radio Rhema, was one of the applicants when the ABA called for applications for the 1386 AM frequency for a community radio station in March 2003; if so, can the Minister also confirm that it demonstrated the highest public interest submission, presenting a membership of some 4,000 persons with over 750 letters in support and representing close to 460,000 persons in the greater Sydney region.
Will the Minister take action to ensure that no further delay occurs in the granting of a Sydney community radio licence on the 1386 AM frequency; if so, what action; if not, why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: At the time that the ABA released its report on the allocation of three community radio broadcasting licences for Sydney, it advised in a news release on 25 May 2001 that it had formed a preliminary view that an additional wide coverage community radio service should be made available in Sydney.

On 24 May 2001, the ABA released a discussion paper and a proposed variation to the Sydney Licence Area Plan which considered the option that another community radio broadcasting service to serve Sydney be made available for allocation, operating on the 1386 kHz frequency. I am advised that after considering the submissions received, the ABA decided to approve the variation to the Sydney Licence Area Plan on 28 March 2002, making an additional community radio broadcasting service available for allocation for the Sydney licence area operating on 1386 kHz.
(3) (a) to (c) The ABA has advised that:

On 27 February 2003, after carefully assessing the applications received the ABA decided not to allocate the licence as it considered that no applicant had adequately demonstrated that it could satisfy all of the criteria at section 84(2) of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992.

On 27 February 2003 the ABA decided not to make the 1386 kHz frequency available for temporary community broadcasting due to problems that had recently been identified in relation to serious electro-magnetic compatibility and possible health and safety issues due to the location of the transmission tower at the nominal transmission site at Homebush Bay and its proximity to new residential areas. The ABA advised that it would review this situation in 12 months time.

In its 10 May 2004 news release, the ABA announced the commencement of its review to explore the issues surrounding the use of the 1386 kHz frequency in Sydney and possible options for its future use in the Sydney licence area. Written submissions were sought from the public in relation to the matters raised in the paper.

item.label: (3) (a)
item.para: to (c) The ABA has advised that:

On 27 February 2003, after carefully assessing the applications received the ABA decided not to allocate the licence as it considered that no applicant had adequately demonstrated that it could satisfy all of the criteria at section 84(2) of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992.

On 27 February 2003 the ABA decided not to make the 1386 kHz frequency available for temporary community broadcasting due to problems that had recently been identified in relation to serious electro-magnetic compatibility and possible health and safety issues due to the location of the transmission tower at the nominal transmission site at Homebush Bay and its proximity to new residential areas. The ABA advised that it would review this situation in 12 months time.

In its 10 May 2004 news release, the ABA announced the commencement of its review to explore the issues surrounding the use of the 1386 kHz frequency in Sydney and possible options for its future use in the Sydney licence area. Written submissions were sought from the public in relation to the matters raised in the paper.

I am advised that the ABA has not made a decision regarding the future use of the 1386 kHz frequency for the Sydney licence area. This decision has been deferred until such time as the Government digital radio policy is further developed.
See answer to Part (4).

I am advised that Sydney Christian Broadcasters Ltd (Rhema Sydney) was one of eight applicants for the community radio broadcasting licence to operate on the 1386 kHz frequency. At the time of submitting its application, Rhema Sydney stated that it had over 4,249 financial members, provided petitions and letters of support with over 7,500 signatories and provided over 500 letters of support from churches. Rhema quoted a 1998 Australian Community Survey that indicated that 20% of the Christian population (476,000 people in Sydney) attended a church on a monthly basis. It claimed a target audience of between 237,000 and 755,000 people; however, did not provide evidence to support this. It should also be noted that there is already a community radio broadcasting service licensed in Sydney to serve this Christian community.

The allocation of licences for community radio broadcasting is a matter for the ABA. The ABA indicated in its 10 May 2004 news release that it is considering a range of options for the use of the frequency including retaining it for a community service, making it available for an open narrowcasting service, using it for Digital Radio Mondiale trials or making it available for other purposes. The ABA is required to consider the appropriate use of the 1386 kHz frequency for Sydney in a manner consistent with the objectives of the Act.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 7 March 2005:

item.para: Is he aware of the community campaign in Wollongong to have the Government allocate an MRI licence to Wollongong Hospital.

Will he list the occasions his office and department have communicated with constituents and community groups in the electoral division of (a) Cunningham and (b) Throsby, including details of the identity of the correspondent and the date and mode of correspondence (ie letter, facsimile, and email), concerning the allocation of an MRI licence to Wollongong Hospital.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: I am aware of the community campaign in Wollongong to extend Medicare eligibility to the MRI unit at Wollongong Hospital.

My Office and my Department have responded to many representations from constituents and community groups regarding the extension of Medicare eligibility to the MRI unit at the Wollongong Hospital. For privacy reasons, I do not feel that it is appropriate to list every such communication.

I should point out that there is a Medicare eligible MRI machine within Wollongong located less than 500 metres from the hospital and that the state government is responsible for the provision of MRI services to public patients in public hospitals.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 7 March 2005:

item.para: Is it the case that Broadband service is not available in all areas of the electoral division of Cunningham; if so, which areas do not have access to Broadband.
What reasons does Telstra give for not providing access to Broadband.
What action is Telstra taking to address this situation.
Is the Minister able to say when Broadband services will be available throughout the electoral division of Cunningham.

talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question based largely on advice from Telstra:

item.para: No, it is not the case. Broadband services are available in all areas of the electoral division of Cunningham through a variety of technology platforms including Asymmetric Digital Subscriber Line (ADSL), CDMA EVDO and other wireless broadband technologies, one way satellite and two way satellite.

There are a number of service providers operating infrastructure to delivers broadband services in the electoral division of Cunningham, including Telstra, Fish Internet, Australian Private Networks, Clear Networks and NewSat. The Australian Government’s Higher Bandwidth Incentive Scheme is providing financial assistance to service providers to enable them to supply services at metropolitan comparable prices to eligible customers within the non-metropolitan parts of the electoral division of Cunningham.
See answer to Part (1).
See answer to Part (1).
See answer to Part (1).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, in writing, on 7 March 2005:

quote.para: When the Joint Offshore Protection Command is established, will it exercise any powers other than those that existed prior to its establishment under Customs legislation or Defence legislation.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

quote.para: The JOPC is not charged with the enforcement of any specific legislation. Its purpose is to strengthen planning, and command and control arrangements for military offshore maritime protection functions and civil maritime surveillance and response.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, in writing, on 7 March 2005:

item.para: Prior to the establishment of the Joint Offshore Protection Command (JOPC), under what power, legislative or otherwise, does the Australian Customs Service (ACS) have authority to order a vessel within the 1000 nautical mile ‘Australian Maritime Information zone’ to report the contents of its cargo.

When the JOPC is established, under what power, legislative or otherwise, will it have authority to order vessels within the 1000 nautical mile ‘Australian Maritime Information zone’ to report to the ACS the contents of its cargo.

Prior to the establishment of the JOPC, what is the jurisdictional limit (in nautical miles) from the coast of the Australian mainland or an Australian Territory for an ACS officer to intercept, board and/or search a vessel and what is the legislative basis for these powers.

When the JOPC is established, what will be the jurisdictional limit (in nautical miles) from the coast of the Australian mainland or any Australian Territory for an ACS officer to intercept, board and/or search a vessel and what will be the legislative basis for these powers.

Has the ACS (a) requested and (b) received any legal advice concerning the ability of the JOPC to order the interdiction of any vessel within the 1000 nautical mile ‘Australian Maritime Information zone’; if so, when was the legal advice (i) sought and (ii) received and (iii) what was the nature of the advice.

Can the Minister confirm that the proposed 1000 nautical mile reporting zone extends five times further than Australia’s existing maritime boundary—the 200nm Exclusive Economic Zone—and overlaps the maritime jurisdiction of Indonesia and New Zealand; if so, what is the legal basis for requiring vessels to report within these areas.
Will the head of the JOPC have authority to make orders and give directions to (a) Australian Customs Service vessels and (b) Australian Defence vessels.

What is the extent of the head of the JOPC’s powers, in particular, will he or she have authority to direct the crew of a (a) Navy and (b) ACS vessel to (i) interdict a vessel, (ii) board a vessel, and (iii) exercise lethal force.
What legislation will the JOPC be responsible for enforcing and will that legislation give the JOPC authority to (a) interdict vessels, (b) board vessels, and (c) exercise coercive force.
What assets will be available to the JOPC, in particular, (a) how many vessels, (b) how many aircraft and (c) what other infrastructure.

Will the JOPC have a role in terms of future strategic planning in respect of border protection and in particular in respect of decisions regarding the future acquisition and use of assets; if so, what.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Section 64AB of the Customs Act 1901 provides the legislative basis for cargo reporting. Sub-section 64AB (8) relevantly states that:
A cargo report is to be made not later than:
When the JOPC is fully established, only vessels proposing to enter Australian ports will be required to provide details of their cargo, as currently required by section 64AB of the Customs Act 1901.
Sections 184A to 185AB provide the legislative basis to board and/or search certain foreign and Australian vessels.

The jurisdiction with respect to Australian ships is based on international law under which States can exercise jurisdiction over their own vessels provided those vessels are not located in the territorial sea of another State.

The jurisdiction with respect to foreign ships falls variously within 12 nautical miles, 24 nautical miles and 200 nautical miles. Australia has sovereignty within the 12 nautical mile territorial sea claimed by Proclamation in the Gazette No. S 297, 1990, under section 7 of the Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973. Therefore, Customs enforces a range of Commonwealth laws.

The jurisdiction with respect to foreign ships between 12 nautical miles and 24 nautical miles is limited to establishing the identity of a ship or, the prevention or punishment of a contravention or an attempted contravention in Australia of the Customs Act 1901 or an Act prescribed by regulations consistently with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). The Acts prescribed are the Migration Act 1958, Quarantine Act 1908, Fisheries Management Act 1991 and the Torres Strait Fisheries Act 1984.

The jurisdiction with respect to foreign ships between 12 nautical miles and 200 nautical miles is the exercise of board and/or search powers where there is a suspicion that that the vessel is, will be or has been involved in a contravention, or attempted contravention, in Australia’s Exclusive Economic Zone of the Fisheries Management Act 1991.

Generally states do not have jurisdiction over foreign ships on the high seas. There are three exceptions to this that allow a boarding to be made and powers to be exercised over foreign ships. The first exception is where an agreement exists between Australia and the flag state of the foreign ship. No such agreements are currently in place. The second exception is to board a ship without nationality to establish the ship’s identity. The third exception is exercising powers over a mother ship that may be on the high seas. That is, although the mother ship is located on the high seas it is linked to a ship closer to Australia (daughter ship) and the two ships are involved in a contravention of Australian law.
As above.
(5) (a) No. (b) No.

item.label: (5) (a)
item.para: No. (b) No.
The Australian Maritime Identification System (AMIS) is not a reporting zone.
At this stage there are no new reporting requirements proposed under the AMIS.

(7) (a) Yes, when Australian Customs Vessels are assigned under operational control to the Commander JOPC for specific operations. (b) Yes, when the ADF vessels are assigned under operational control to the Commander JOPC for specific operations.

item.label: (7) (a)
item.para: Yes, when Australian Customs Vessels are assigned under operational control to the Commander JOPC for specific operations. (b) Yes, when the ADF vessels are assigned under operational control to the Commander JOPC for specific operations.

For military operations and combined exercises, the Chief of Defence Force (CDF) will assign ADF forces to the Chief of Joint Operations (CJOPS). Within any constraints imposed by CDF, CJOPS will command the operation or activity directly, or may nominate the Commander JOPC as the commander of an operation or exercise.

For the conduct of civil and Customs operations and joint/combined exercises, the Chief Executive Officer Australian Customs Service (CEO Customs) will assign airborne surveillance assets, and may direct other assets such as Australian Customs Vessels, to the Commander JOPC for his/her control and management for specific operations or exercises.
The Commander JOPC will issue orders that accord with the Rules of Engagement (ROE) promulgated by CDF through CJOPS and by the CEO Customs.

JOPC is not charged with the enforcement of any specific legislation. Its purpose is to simplify and strengthen planning, as well as command and control arrangements for military offshore maritime protection functions and the conduct of civil maritime surveillance.

There are 8 Australian Customs Vessels; 17 Coastwatch aircraft; 15 Navy Fremantle Class Patrol Boats and 12 Navy Armidale Patrol Boats yet to be delivered. In September 2004 Government announced the acquisition of an additional two Armidale Class patrol boats.
The number assigned to JOPC will vary depending on Customs and Defence tasking priorities and requirements.
The JOPC will contribute to future strategic planning, particularly in respect to the counter-terrorism aspects of border protection.

It is also anticipated that JOPC will have input in respect of decisions regarding the acquisition and use of assets, although JOPC will not own any of the particular assets. It is intended that JOPC will use Customs and ADF assets to execute a particular operation during a particular period and at the end of that operation, hand back control of the asset.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, in writing, on 7 March 2005:

item.para: How many Australian Federal Police (AFP) officers are based at the AFP station in the Torres Strait.
How many AFP officers are currently assigned to conduct joint patrols to combat transnational crime between PNG and Australia.
Does the AFP plan to introduce any other measures to combat the drug trade between PNG and Australia.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: There are two AFP employees based full time on Thursday Island, with additional support provided by the AFP’s Cairns Office as required.

The AFP in North Queensland participates with State and Commonwealth agencies in all joint cross border-patrols between Australia and PNG. The number of AFP members deployed varies in proportion to the circumstances and the objectives of the patrol.

The AFP is working closely with State and Commonwealth agencies at both a tactical and strategic level to counteract the illicit drug trade between Australia and PNG. On available evidence, current strategies are sufficient and effective, however operational and intelligence practices targeting illicit drug activity in the Torres Strait are monitored and reviewed as required.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, in writing, on 7 March 2005:

item.para: What measures, procedures or policies does the Australian Federal Police (AFP) have in place to replace the occupants of the positions held by AFP officers in Australia prior to their deployment overseas.
What tasks, activities or positions have AFP officers been removed from prior to their deployment to Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands.
Do any of these tasks, activities or positions presently remain unfilled; if so, which ones.

What procedures are there to assist with the transition of files and/or investigations from an AFP officer who is being deployed overseas to the AFP officer assuming responsibility for that file or investigation.
Have any files and or investigations been left in abeyance as a result of overseas deployments.

Has the AFP conducted an inquiry or requested a report on the effect of the deployment of AFP officers overseas on the ability of the AFP to deliver key capabilities in Australia; if so, what are the details and the findings.

Does the AFP intend to conduct an inquiry or has the AFP requested a report on the effect of the deployment of AFP officers overseas on the ability of the AFP to deliver key capabilities in Australia; if so, when; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

quote.para: The AFP has a sophisticated and pre-existing methodology for accepting, allocating and monitoring matters referred to it for investigation. In considering acceptance or rejection of referrals the AFP applies its Case Categorisation & Prioritisation Model (CCPM). Decisions to accept or reject a referral take into account a number of variables including CCPM classification, referral evaluation and recommendation, and available capacity.

The AFP has a number of publicly available stated performance measures against which it monitors its outputs. The AFP makes decisions on the allocation of capacity to crime types and geographical offices based on its understanding of the criminal activity and the requirements of client agencies. As part of its regular performance review, the AFP monitors the potential displacement of current activities by the demands of emerging threats. In particular, the AFP has been vigilant to the possible impact of its overseas operations on its ability to conduct domestic criminal investigations.

The AFP monitors its activity through operational hours allocated to a matter and through the results achieved. Performance reports are provided to the National Managers Group each month and to the Executive Management Board every two months, and these provide an opportunity for a number of interventions to occur where decisions concerning resource allocations are seen to impact work delivery. The nature of the AFP’s core activities has changed over the past five years especially with respect to overseas operations. The impact of these changes on domestic operations has been minimal both in terms of activity levels and results achieved.
Details of the impact on domestic operations is included in the following answers addressing your specific questions.

item.para: The IDG deployment force is made up of resources from the AFP’s Outcome 1 areas, ACT Policing and from State Police forces. In order to permit the deployment of resources without impact on domestic operations the AFP has specifically a) recruited staff into ACT Policing and specifically into the IDG, b) encouraged voluntary movement of staff across the AFP business streams, c) has redirected some work to offices with available capacity and d) seconded staff to international work directly from state police services.

AFP staff do not move to the IDG permanently, but for an agreed period of deployment. This arrangement allows for a fixed term allocation, which in turn is covered through a backfilling strategy. For example a 70-week EOI process allows staff to voluntarily apply to fixed length transfer to encourage movement across AFP business streams to maintain appropriate resource levels. This movement is balanced by recruitment strategies which to date have seen more than 170 staff come into the AFP. The recruitment strategies target a balance between fixed term engagement and permanent appointment to the AFP.

The AFP examines the operational case load of each deployed officer well in advance of deployment, and makes decisions about case load and allocation. Prior to deploying a member overseas or to another geographic location the member and their supervisor review cases allocated to the member to identify cases that can be completed prior to deployment and those needing re-allocating to a new case manager. Because of the resource management decisions taken, and because the management of case load is continually reviewed, the AFP has experienced minimal impact on its domestic operations because of its IDG involvement. Performance measures quoted in the following answers, particularly to Question 6, demonstrate this position.

Prior to deploying a member overseas or to another geographic location, the member and their supervisor review cases allocated to the member to identify cases that can be completed prior to deployment and those needing re-allocated to a new case officer. When a case is re-allocated the new case officer is provided with briefing and reviews case situation reports to become appraised of the case. In the case of major investigations a second case officer and/or core team may be allocated to the investigation to ensure continuity of investigation.

The number of matters rejected is indicative both of internal resource availability and demands by client agencies. Matters rejected increased from a low of 184 in 2000 to a peak of 389 in 2002 (impacted by the Bali bombing investigation), but have since declined to 288 in 2004.

The AFP has committed itself to investigating serious crime. Over the five years from 2000 to 2004, the number of High or Very High Impact matters has increased from 386 new cases in 2000 to 700 new cases in 2004.
Over the same period, the total number of domestic cases has decreased by 19%, primarily because minor matters have increasingly been handled by alternative strategies, e.g. outposted officers.
The number of cases finalised has remained steady over the period.

The number of cases resulting in convictions has increased from 282 in 2000 to 300 in 2004. The quantity of illegal drugs seized has remained high over the five-year period increasing from 2.0 tonne in 2000 to 2.6 tonne in 2004. Results in the intervening years are variable.
Over the past five years, the AFP has met its Portfolio Budget Target of 65% of resources devoted to High or Very High Impact matters.
As indicated above, the AFP will continue to monitor the impact of emerging operational activity on traditional law enforcement activity.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, in writing, on 7 March 2005:

item.para: To what extent is information acquired in criminal investigations shared between the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and state law enforcement agencies.
Is there a common computer network available to both Commonwealth and State law enforcement agencies for use in investigations as opposed to the information contained in Crimtrac.

In circumstances where an AFP officer is investigating a matter, are there procedures or computer systems that automatically advise a state police officer investigating a related matter of additional information that may be added to the AFP investigation files.
Are there procedures or computer systems that automatically advise AFP officers of additional information which may be added to State databases.

In circumstances where an AFP officer is investigating a matter, are there procedures or computer systems that automatically advise ASIO of any additional information that may be added to the Federal investigation files.
Are there such procedures or computer systems that automatically advise AFP officers of additional information which may be added to ASIO databases.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Information acquired during criminal investigations is shared between the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and State law enforcement agencies to the extent necessary to achieve effective and efficient operational outcomes under the relevant legislative and governance frameworks.

No. Joint investigations between the AFP and State law enforcement agencies utilise liaison officers who have access to agency on line services. Joint initiatives between the Commonwealth and State law enforcement agencies are further supplemented by installing AFP and relevant State agencies on line services within the joint investigative team to service the requirements of the investigation. Information is readily shared between the Commonwealth and State law enforcement agencies through the application of a variety of non AFP information systems when appropriate.

There are no computer systems which automatically advise either the AFP or State law enforcement agencies of information regarding an investigation. However procedures have been implemented to facilitate information flow between agencies. In any investigation regular consultation occurs between agencies and in many instances agencies are co-located to facilitate information flow. The appointment of agency liaison officers to investigations assists in cross-agency information sharing. The AFP and State police conduct nation wide criminal history checks to access cross-jurisdictional information regarding persons of interest. AFP computer terminals are being progressively installed in State Police Operation Centres (POC) to enable access to AFP systems for specific incidents or investigations.
Refer to response (3) above.

No. Security protocols do not allow shared computer systems between the AFP and ASIO. There are procedures which facilitate information exchange between ASIO and the AFP. The AFP and ASIO have established a close working relationship, and share information through formal written request and verbally through regular case officer and senior management meetings.
Refer to response (5) above.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 7 March 2005:

quote.para: Since Mr Willie Brigitte was deported from Australia, has ASIO had access to Mr Brigitte for the purpose of conducting an interview; if not, has ASIO or any other government agency sought access.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: I have responded to questions dealing with Attorney-General’s Department and Australian Federal Police access to Mr Brigitte (Question Numbers 84 and 283 asked on 2 December 2004 in Senate Estimates – copies of those replies are attached).

Given the fact that Mr Brigitte is the subject of a current judicial investigation in France and there are legal processes underway in Australia, it would not be appropriate for ASIO to comment further on this matter.
Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee
Attorney-General’s Department
Output 2.2

Willie Brigitte

item.label: (a)
item.para: Has the Attorney-General’s Department sought any contact with Mr Brigitte following his expulsion from Australia?

item.label: (b)
item.para: If so, has the Attorney-General’s Department actually made any such contact?

item.label: (c)
item.para: If so, what was the nature of that contact?

item.label: (d)
item.para: If so, has Attorney-General’s Department sought any legal advice in relation to this issue?

quote.para: The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: to (d) No.

quote.para: Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee Australian Federal Police
Question No. 283
Senator Ludwig asked the following question on 2 December 2004:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Has the AFP sought any contact with Mr Brigitte following his expulsion from Australia?

item.label: (b)
item.para: If so, has the AFP actually made any such contact?

item.label: (c)
item.para: If so, what was the nature of that contact?

item.label: (d)
item.para: If so, has the AFP sought any legal advice in relation to this issue?

quote.para: The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Yes. On 7 April 2004, members of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) attended the Paris offices of French Judge Bruguiere and attempted to interview Mr Willy Virgile Brigitte.

item.label: (b)
item.para: No. Mr Brigitte declined to speak to AFP officers.

item.label: (c)
item.para: See the answer to question (b).

item.label: (d)
item.para: The AFP regularly liaises with the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions and the Attorney-General’s Department on this matter.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 7 March 2005:

item.para: Is he aware of a report prepared by the Parliamentary Library ‘Medication for Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD): an analysis by Federal Electorate (2001 – 03)’.
Can he explain the variation in prescriptions for dexamphetamine sulfate between electoral divisions; if not, why not.
Does he plan to investigate the diagnosis and treatment of ADHD; if so, how will this be conducted and when; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: I am aware of the report prepared by the Parliamentary Library ‘Medication for Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD): analysis by Federal Electorate (2001–03).

From the data provided in the Electorate reports it is not possible to provide a simple explanation for the variation between electoral divisions in the prescribing of dexamphetamine. Establishing the reasons for such variations is complicated by the uncertainty of the data. Dexamphetamine is currently the only drug listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) specifically for the treatment of ADHD. As dexamphetamine is priced under the general patient co-payment of $28.60, there is limited available information on the number of prescriptions and prescribing patterns. The Health Insurance Commission only collects data where a Government benefit is paid. As such we do not have data on prescriptions that cost less than the general co-payment amount. In addition, as dexamphetamine is classified as a Schedule 8 medicine (see 3 below), the states and territories are responsible for collecting data on the prescribing of these drugs.

I encourage best practice in providing guidance to doctors on the quality use of medicines. Best practice guidance comes through sources such as the National Health and Medical Research Council and through National Health Priorities initiatives.

The Australian Government does not regulate the treatment and prescribing practices of doctors. The decision to prescribe medications, including medicines for the treatment of ADHD, is a judgment made by a doctor approved to prescribe by their respective state and territory health departments with regard to individual circumstances.

The states and territories regulate the prescribing of some drugs as they are classified as Schedule 8 Drugs – drugs of addiction. Most states and territories only allow dexamphetamine to be prescribed by an ‘authorised’ prescriber, such as a consultant pediatrician or a consultant psychiatrist.
Medicines for ADHD should always be prescribed as part of a comprehensive treatment program which includes psychological, educational and social remedial measures.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 8 March 2005:

item.para: Can he confirm that pharmaceutical products and other treatments are available for patients withdrawing from (a) illicit drug, (b) alcohol, and (c) cigarette use through programs and schemes provided through his department.

Can he provide the (a) details and (b) costs of each program and scheme that provides pharmaceutical products and other treatments available for patients withdrawing from (i) illicit drug, (ii) alcohol, and (iii) cigarette use.
For each year since 2000, (a) what was the estimated cost borne by the taxpayer, and (b) how many deaths were attributed to (i) illicit drug, (ii) alcohol, and (iii) cigarette use.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: (b) and (c) The Australian Government has programs that increase the availability of pharmaceutical products for treating dependence on heroin, alcohol, and tobacco. However, the provision of drug and alcohol detoxification (withdrawal) programs is primarily the responsibility of State and Territory Governments.

(2) (a) and (b) (i) (ii) and (iii) There is a general Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme subsidy for two drugs used in treating alcohol dependence (acamprosate calcium and naltrexone hydrochloride), and one drug used in treating nicotine dependence (buproprion hydrochloride).
In 2003-04, the cost of acamprosate was $3,473,441, naltrexone was $2,078,329, and buproprion was $14,390,389.

Under section 100 of the National Health Act 1953, the Australian Government also funds the cost of (a) bulk purchases of methadone hydrochloride syrup supplied to pharmacies, clinics, and hospitals for the management of opiate dependence; and

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: and (b) (i) (ii) and (iii) There is a general Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme subsidy for two drugs used in treating alcohol dependence (acamprosate calcium and naltrexone hydrochloride), and one drug used in treating nicotine dependence (buproprion hydrochloride).
In 2003-04, the cost of acamprosate was $3,473,441, naltrexone was $2,078,329, and buproprion was $14,390,389.

Under section 100 of the National Health Act 1953, the Australian Government also funds the cost of (a) bulk purchases of methadone hydrochloride syrup supplied to pharmacies, clinics, and hospitals for the management of opiate dependence; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: the supply of buprenorphine hydrochloride tablets as recommended for the treatment of opiate dependence, including maintenance and detoxification (withdrawal) within a framework of medical, social and psychological treatment. The funding is by way of reimbursement to the wholesale supplier or importer of the drug. In 2003-04, the cost of methadone to the Australian Government was $4,336,285 and of buprenorphine $15,982,495.
Other treatments are the responsibility of state and territory governments.

(3) (a) The most recent data on the costs of drug use are for 1998-99. The study, Counting the cost: estimates of the social costs of drug abuse in Australia in 1998-9 was published in 2002. There is no estimate of how much of the total social cost was borne by taxpayers. However, the table at Attachment A shows the estimated tangible costs (such as lost productivity and hospital costs) for illicit drugs, alcohol and tobacco, and the estimated proportion of those costs borne by the government sector, including state and territory governments. The remaining costs were borne by industry and by individuals.

item.label: (3) (a)
item.para: The most recent data on the costs of drug use are for 1998-99. The study, Counting the cost: estimates of the social costs of drug abuse in Australia in 1998-9 was published in 2002. There is no estimate of how much of the total social cost was borne by taxpayers. However, the table at Attachment A shows the estimated tangible costs (such as lost productivity and hospital costs) for illicit drugs, alcohol and tobacco, and the estimated proportion of those costs borne by the government sector, including state and territory governments. The remaining costs were borne by industry and by individuals.

item.label: (b)
item.para: (i) (ii) and (iii) Mortality data is predominantly provided by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) and is based on registered death certificates received from state and territory registrars of births, deaths and marriages.

Deaths are classified according to ICD-10-AM which is the international statistical classification of diseases and health related problems. ICD-10-AM classifications of deaths from causes including drug use are attributed to the event leading to the death rather than by the specific drug per se. For example, death may be recorded as caused by lung cancer (malignant neoplasm) or a motor vehicle accident. Hence, information on drug-related deaths is not available for every year since 2000.

For alcohol and tobacco, the Department has estimates of deaths derived using the aetiological fraction methodology. This methodology relies on the prevalence of a risk factor and associated relative risk of a particular illness or injury. According to the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, the aetiological fractions methodology shows that in 1998 some 19,019 people died in Australia as a result of tobacco smoking. Information from the National Drug Research Institute for alcohol shows that in 2001 an estimated 3,004 people died as a consequence of risky or high risk levels of alcohol consumption.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics Information Paper (2003) Drug Induced Deaths 2001 provides some information about deaths attributed to drug use (excluding alcohol, tobacco and volatile substances) in Australia. This indicated that in 2001 there were 1,038 drug-induced deaths registered.
Attachment A
Tangible costs of drug abuse in 1998-9

entry.para: Tangible costs borne by government sector ($m)

item.para: Source: Collins, DJ and Lapsley, HM (2001) Counting the cost: estimates of the social costs of drug abuse in Australia in 1998-9, National Drug Strategy Monograph No. 49. Canberra: Department of Health and Ageing

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 8 March 2005:

item.para: How many s417 applications are currently before the Minister.
How many s417 applications have been delegated to the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs to determine.
On what basis are s417 applications divided between the Minister and the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs.
What is the average processing time for s417 applications from receipt to decision.
What proportion of s417 applications are from people currently in immigration detention.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: As at 28 February 2005, there were 1824 s417 requests before both the Minister and the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs. It should be noted that there is no application for Ministerial Intervention under s417. Section 417 of the Migration Act 1958 provides the Minister with the power to substitute for a decision of the Refugee Review Tribunal, a decision which is more favourable to the applicant, if the Minister considers that it is in the public interest to do so. This power is not compellable and the Minister does not have an obligation to consider substituting a more favourable decision in a case. In all cases where a review authority affirms a decision on a Protection Visa application, an assessment against the Minister’s guidelines is undertaken by the Department. If the case falls within the guidelines, a submission is prepared to enable the Minister to decide whether he or she wishes to consider the case for intervention.

The s417 power is not delegated. Both Ministers exercise their s417 Ministerial Intervention power in their own right. The division of cases between the two Ministers is broadly determined by whether or not the cases are deemed to be made by individuals in the community or cases deemed to be made by individuals in detention. The division of responsibilities for s417 Ministerial Intervention cases between portfolio Ministers is determined by categories and not by the number of cases.

Under administrative arrangements put in place after Minister McGauran was appointed as Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs on 26 October 2004, Senator Vanstone handles section 417 intervention cases covering people in detention, while Mr McGauran handles the intervention cases covering people who are not in detention.

Departmental systems do not maintain statistics on average processing times for Ministerial Intervention processes in a reportable format. Variations in processing may be determined by the individual aspects of a particular case. The power for the Minister to intervene is exhausted only when finalisation of the case is determined. Every person whose case is brought to the Minister’s attention is advised of his or her decision, whether it is a decision to refuse to consider exercising the public interest powers, or a decision following consideration of the exercise of those powers.
As at 28 February 2005, there were 1824 requests processed by the Department or being considered by the Minister. Of these, nine per cent or 171 requests were detention cases.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, in writing, on 8 March 2005:

item.para: Further to the answer to question No. 82 (Hansard, 8 February 2005, pages 82-87), for each financial year from 2000-01 to 2003-04, what sum was provided to each (a) private and (b) community based child care centre in the electoral division of Throsby within the Child Care Rebate range (i) 1 to 25 per cent CCB, (ii) 26 to 50 per cent CCB, (iii) 51 to 75 per cent CCB, and (iv) 76 to 100 per cent CCB.
Can the Minister confirm that 70 per cent of child care places for children 0-2 years of age in the electoral division of Throsby are being delivered through the community-based sector.
What strategies are being implemented to support the community-based sector to provide more childcare places for children 0-2 years of age.
Are there any requirements for private providers in areas of high demand to provide places for children under 2 years of age; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: (b) (i) (ii) (iii) (iv) Child Care Benefit expenditure for each financial year from 2000-01 to 2003-04 for the electoral division of Throsby by quartile of CCB percentage for private and community child care is as follows:
Notes:
1. Excludes CCB not received as a reduction in service fees
2. Total includes CCB expenditure where customer’s CCB percentage could not be determined.
3. Customer’s CCB percentage determined as his/her most recent assessment during the financial year.
4. Nationally weighted data.
5. The CCB percentage categories, ‘1 to 25’ and ‘75+’ cross over more than one rate of Child Care Benefit.
Source: Centrelink administrative data.

While the number of 0-2 year old places licenced by the State Government can be determined, it is not possible to know how many of these places are actually being offered at any one time in the electoral division of Throsby due to flexible licensing arrangements and individual service operating practices.

The Long Day Care Incentive Scheme provides not-for-profit and for-profit providers with short term incentives to encourage the establishment of new viable long day care centres in rural and urban fringe areas of high unmet demand.

The funding for Long Day Care Incentive Scheme encourages additional places for children under 24 months through the provision of higher per place funding to this age group. Places for children under 2 years receive $30 per place, per week incentive funding and places for over 2 years receive $15 per place, per week incentive funding.

Sustainability Assistance is available to existing eligible not-for-profit Long Day Care services. It is targeted to areas of need approved by the department as a contribution to support viability. Sustainability Assistance gives a higher weighting to services that have places for children under 24 months.

There are no requirements for private providers in areas of high demand to provide places for children under 2 years of age. However, through the Long Day Care Incentive Scheme, services in rural and urban fringe areas of high unmet demand are encouraged to have places for this age group through the provision of higher per place funding for children under 24 months.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on 8 March 2005:

item.para: What sum was provided in 2004 to (a) government, and (b) non-government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and in the postcode area (i) 4699, (ii) 4700, (iii) 4701, (iv) 4702, (v) 4703, (vi) 4704, (vii) 4705, (viii) 4706, (ix) 4707, (x) 4710, (xi) 4712, (xii) 4713, (xiii) 4714, (xiv) 4715, (xv) 4716, (xvi) 4717, (xvii) 4718, (xviii) 4719, (xix) 4721, (xx) 4741, (xxi) 4742, (xxii) 4743, (xxiii) 4744, (xxiv) 4745, (xxv) 4746, and (xxvi) 4804.
What was the (a) expenditure on, (b) location of, and (c) purpose of each grant in 2004.

What sum will be provided in 2005 to (a) government, and (b) non-government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and the postcode area (i) 4699, (ii) 4700, (iii) 4701, (iv) 4702, (v) 4703, (vi) 4704, (vii) 4705, (viii) 4706, (ix) 4707, (x) 4710, (xi) 4712, (xii) 4713, (xiii) 4714, (xiv) 4715, (xv) 4716, (xvi) 4717, (xvii) 4718, (xviii) 4719, (xix) 4721, (xx) 4741, (xxi) 4742, (xxii) 4743, (xxiii) 4744, (xxiv) 4745, (xxv) 4746, and (xxvi) 4804.
What will (a) the expenditure be for, (b) be the location of, and (c) be the purpose of each grant in 2005.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr Nelson

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Total Australian Government funding for government schools is not reported at the level of detail requested. Australian Government General Recurrent Grants for government schools are provided to the government education authority in each State or Territory, on the basis to total enrolments. The State or Territory determines where the grants are used. Payments to individual schools are not recorded.

The Department of Education, Science and Training only provides postcode detail for General Recurrent Grants and Establishment Grants to non-government schools, and Capital Grants, Flagpole funding and funding for the Boys’ Education Lighthouse Schools (BELS) project to both government and non‑government schools. In 2004, Flagpole funding amounting to $2,753 was provided to government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes. No Capital or BELS funding was provided to government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes in 2004.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Total Australian Government funding for non-government schools cannot be reported at the level of detail requested. Funding from Australian Government programmes that can be reported at this level of detail for non-government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and identified post codes totalled $33,028,552.60. Of this amount, Capital Grants funding provided $269,995, Flagpole funding provided $1,500 and General Recurrent Grants funding provided $32,757,057.60 to non‑government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes for 2004. No Establishment Grant funding or BELS funding was provided to non-government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes in 2004.

(2) (a) (b) Details on the expenditure and location for the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes for 2004 are as follows: Flagpole Funding to government schools is at Table 1, Attachment A; Capital Grants to non-government schools is at Table 2, Attachment A; Flagpole Funding to non‑government schools is at Table 3, Attachment A; and General Recurrent funding to non-government schools is at Table 4 at Attachment A.

item.label: (c)
item.para: The purpose of the Australian Government Capital Grants is to assist in the provision of school facilities, particularly in ways that contribute most to raising the overall level of educational achievement of Australian school students.
The purpose of Flagpole funding is to assist schools with their civics and citizenship education activities, and promoting values education in Australian schools.

The purpose of Australian Government General Recurrent Grants is to help schools with the recurrent cost of school education so that they can offer students education directed towards the achievement of the Australian Government’s priorities for schooling.

(3) (a) Estimates of total Australian Government funding for 2005 for government schools are not maintained at the level of detail requested (see response to 1a). Information about 2005 Capital Grants for government schools is not yet available. To date, no Flagpole funding or BELS funding has been provided to government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes in 2005.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Estimates of total Australian Government funding for 2005 for non-government schools are not maintained at the level of detail requested. Estimated funding from Australian Government Programmes that can be reported at this level of detail for non-government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes amounted to $37,278,600 for 2005. Of this amount, Capital Grants funding will provide an estimated $902,667 and General Recurrent Grants funding will provide an estimated $36,375,933 for non‑government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes for 2005. To date, no Flagpole funding, Establishment or BELS funding has been provided to non-government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes for 2005.

(4) (a) and (b) Details on the estimated expenditure and location for the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes for 2005 are as follows: Estimated Capital grants to non-government schools is at Table 5 at Attachment A; Estimated General Recurrent Grants to non-government schools is at Table 6 at Attachment A.

item.label: (c)
item.para: The purpose of the Australian Government Capital Grants is to assist in the provision of school facilities, particularly in ways that contribute most to raising the overall level of educational achievement of Australian school students.

The purpose of Australian Government General Recurrent Grants is to help schools with the recurrent cost of school education so that they can offer students education directed towards the achievement of the Australian Government’s priorities for schooling.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, in writing, on 8 March 2005:

item.para: How many Job Network providers are currently operating in the electoral division of Capricornia and what are their names and addresses.
How many job seekers are currently registered with (a) each Job Network provider, and (b) each office of each provider operating in the electoral division of Capricornia.

For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, in (i) Australia, and (ii) the electoral division of Capricornia, how many Newstart or Youth Allowance recipients were placed into jobs through assistance from Job Network providers.

For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many long-term unemployed people (i) in total, and (ii) as a proportion of all unemployed people, participated in intensive assistance programs in the electoral division of Capricornia.

For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many of the people who participated in intensive assistance in the electoral division of Capricornia have participated on (i) one occasion, (ii) two occasions, (iii) three occasions, and (iv) more than three occasions.

For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many job seekers who participated in intensive assistance in the electoral division of Capricornia found employment and what proportion found (i) full-time, (ii) part-time, and (iii) casual employment.
How many Work for the Dole providers are currently operating in the electoral division of Capricornia, what are their names and addresses and what programs do they offer.
For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many people who participated in a Work for the Dole program in the electoral division of Capricornia found employment.

For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, what proportion of people who participated in a Work for the Dole program in the electoral division of Capricornia found (i) full-time, (ii) part-time, and (iii) casual employment following their placement.

For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many people who participated in a Work for the Dole program in the electoral division of Capricornia were in (i) full-time, (ii) part-time, and (iii) casual employment three months after completing their placement.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr Andrews

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: and (2) Job Network is administered on the basis of 19 Labour Market Regions and 137 Employment Services Areas (ESAs), the boundaries of which do not align with those of Federal Electorates. Job seekers choose Job Network members for a variety of reasons including location, proximity to transport routes and Centrelink offices, or the satisfaction of friends and others. Job seekers residing in one Electorate or ESA may be assisted through Job Network sites located in adjoining Electorates or ESAs. For illustration, job seekers residing in the Electorate of Capricornia may be assisted through Job Network sites located in the Electorates of Dawson, Kennedy, Maranoa or Hinkler. The Emerald ESA, Gladstone ESA, Mackay ESA, Rockhampton ESA and Townsville ESA are most closely aligned with the Electorate of Capricornia and, therefore, answers are provided with reference to these five ESAs.

There are currently 12 Job Network members and other Job Placement Organisations operating in the Emerald ESA, 11 in the Gladstone ESA, 20 in the Mackay ESA, 18 in the Rockhampton ESA and 40 in the Townsville ESA. Their names, office locations and the number of job seekers on their caseloads are shown in Table 1.
