talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on 8 March 2005:

item.para: Can he confirm that the Socio-Economic Status (SES) funding formula is an aggregate statistic measuring the economic status of districts and not individual families or individual schools; if not, why not.

Can he confirm that the SES funding formula gives a potentially misleading indicator of educational need and results in the overly generous funding of some independent non-government schools with boarding facilities; if not, why not.
Will the Government review the formula used to allocate Commonwealth funding to independent schools; if so, when; if not, why not.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr Nelson

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The SES methodology calculates an SES score for each school based on all the Census Collection Districts (CDs) from which the school draws it students. The data present an average socioeconomic profile of the school community, that is, the families of students at the school. The SES model does not set out to measure the wealth of any individual family or school, but rather to rank schools relative to each other based on the SES of each school’s community.

Following the SES Simulation Project undertaken in 1998, a series of validation exercises were carried out using the simulation results against other parental income and wealth measures. The findings of the validation exercises support the view that a Census-based SES measure produces a good proxy for parental socioeconomic status, without the intrusiveness and administrative complexity inherent in measuring parental income more directly.

The SES approach is a transparent and objective measure based on Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Census data that are consistent for all schools. The SES Index that is used to calculate schools’ SES scores measures the income, education and occupation levels of all residents within a CD. The SES score of each student’s home CD is the only factor that contributes to the school’s SES score. There is no discrimination between boarding and non‑boarding students.

Data collected by the Department of Education, Science and Training in 2003 show that there were over 140 independent boarding schools, enrolling some 11,000 boarding students. These students come from a wide range of CDs in both urban and rural areas, with about 45 per cent coming from urban areas.

The data also show that schools with boarding students are not advantaged by the SES funding formula. In many instances, boarding schools which are located in the same area as day schools have a similar or higher SES score than the day schools. For example:
· there are two boarding schools located in Wahroonga, NSW; the four other non-government schools located in this suburb all have lower SES scores

· in Hawthorn, Victoria there are six non-government schools, one of which is an boarding school with an SES score of 124; three of the remaining schools have scores below 124 while the other two have scores of 125
· there are five schools located in Brisbane, one of which is a boarding school with an SES score of 116; the other four schools have scores of 102, 113, 117 and 119
· the two boarding schools in the ACT have SES scores of 119 and 124; the 13 other schools in the ACT, which also cater for secondary students, have scores ranging from 100 to 122.

A review of the SES funding arrangements will be undertaken during the current quadrennium. The review will involve consultations with all non‑government school groups and these discussions will inform policy development for the funding of non‑government schools for 2009‑2012.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 9 March 2005:

(2) Broadband services are available in all of these areas through a variety of technology platforms including ADSL, CDMA EVDO and other wireless broadband technologies, and One-Way and Two-Way satellite. Further, the Australian Government’s Higher Bandwidth Incentive Scheme is providing financial assistance to service providers to enable them to supply services at metropolitan comparable prices to eligible customers within the electoral division of Hunter.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, in writing, on 9 March 2005:

item.para: What is the Government doing to relieve pressure on fruit and vegetable growers who are experiencing falling income due to increased costs?
What assistance is available to farmers who are currently experiencing loss of income?
What is the Government doing to assist fruit and vegetable growers meet increased costs?

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr Truss

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: While it would be inappropriate to directly intervene in private sector markets, the Government has introduced a range of measures to improve the competitiveness of fruit and vegetable growers. The Government has gained improved access to export markets for fruit and vegetable growers and recently introduced legislation to amend the Trade Practices Act to make it quicker, simpler and easier to collectively negotiate with buyers of their produce. The Government also provides matching research and development funding for fruit and vegetable industries, to help them lower industry costs and provides support for industry training.

There are a number of Government programs available to assist farmers experiencing a loss of income. The Agriculture – Advancing Australia Farm Help Program, is the Government’s key means of providing short term income support to low-income farm families who are experiencing financial hardship. There is also Exceptional Circumstances Assistance for farmers experiencing a severe and prolonged decline in income due to a rare and severe event. Interim income support is also available where a prima facie case for Exceptional Circumstances Assistance has been demonstrated.

The Government helps farmers including fruit and vegetable growers face challenges such as increased costs through its Agriculture – Advancing Australia package of programs. This package of programs is targeted at helping producers become more competitive, sustainable and profitable by improving business management, supporting families through change, providing access to professional advice, improving access to markets and building industry capacity to meet future challenges. Australian Government funding of over $1 billion since 1997 for these programs demonstrates the Government’s strong commitment to ensuring the long-term prosperity of rural and regional Australia.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 9 March 2005:

item.para: Is the Minister aware of reports that the Joint Strike Fighter’s (JSF) development costs have risen to about $38 billion.

Is the Minister aware that part of the reported increase is being attributed to the United States Department of Defense’s demand for anti-tampering safeguards to prevent sensitive technologies being passed on to enemies.
If Australia decides to purchase the JSF, will Australia have access to technology in key areas including the weapons’ guidance and navigation systems in the JSF.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

The Minister is aware of the United States requirement for anti-tamper software to protect sensitive JSF technologies. However, the specific element of the breakdown of costs for the increase is not yet known.
Defence staff have been provided with detailed classified briefings on the high level of JSF capability that will be offered to Australia to allow us to operate and support the JSF.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: The Defence Materiel Organisation obtained 59 generators from the UK Ministry of Defence. BAE Systems refurbished 39 generators within the scope of the Rapier Life of Type Extension Project (LAND 140). A sole-source contract was raised with BAE Systems for the refurbishment of the remaining 20 generators. Subsequently, a tender was raised for the modification of these 20 generators.

item.label: (a)
item.para: Advanced Power.

item.label: (b)
item.para: 4 February 2003.

item.label: (c)
item.para: Yes, on 31 January 2003.
The debriefing of the unsuccessful tenderer occurred by telephone in early 2003 and was followed up by a letter dated 21 March 2003.

No. Investigations established that commercially available new generators would need to be modified to meet the power requirements; the cost of the new generators, plus modifications, was substantially greater than the cost of the refurbished generators. Furthermore, there were advantages of commonality with existing generators in refurbishing and modifying the United Kingdom-sourced generators.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 March 2005:

quote.para: How many (a) psychiatrists, (b) doctors, and (c) interpreters speaking (i) Farsi/Dari, (ii) Pashtun, (iii) Uzbek and (iv) Tajik have been employed or contracted by the department or its contractors in Australian detention centres or alternative holding centres.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) utilises a number of psychiatrists, psychologists and counsellors in its immigration detention facilities, in the following manner:

- At Baxter Immigration Detention Facility (IDF), a psychiatrist visits approximately every 6 weeks, depending on case requirements. One psychologist and one counsellor are also available during business hours, Monday to Friday.

- At Villawood Immigration Detention Centre (IDC), an onsite General Practitioner (GP) refers clients to a private off-site psychiatrist. For acute and/or urgent treatment, a Mental Health Unit can be accessed via Bankstown Emergency department (Banks House). In addition, there is one full-time psychologist and three part-time psychologists on-site.

- At Maribyrnong IDC, there is a visiting psychiatrist who attends every 4 to 6 weeks. For acute and/or urgent treatment, either Werribee Mercy Hospital Psychiatric Unit can be accessed via Outpatient appointment or tele-consultation may take place via Crises Assessment and Treatment (CAT) Service. In addition, there is one full-time psychologist and one part-time counsellor on-site and one psychologist on call to see detainees on a needs basis.

- At Perth IDC, non-emergency, tele-consultations may take place with a psychiatrist, as well as outpatient appointments via Bentley Clinic. Acute or non-acute consultations or non-voluntary admissions may take place via Bentley and Greylands Hospitals. There is also one part-time psychologist on-site.

- At Christmas Island Immigration Reception and Processing Centre (IRPC), a GP may consult with WA Mental Health Services via the phone. Acute psychiatric patients may be sent to Perth. A visiting psychologist attends one week per month.

item.label: (b)
item.para: DIMIA also utilises a number of doctors in its immigration detention facilities, in the following manner:
- At Baxter IDF, one doctor attends a daily GP clinic on-site, Monday to Friday. There is also one doctor on-call 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

- At Villawood IDC, three doctors provide five clinics from Monday to Friday, and one doctor provides a clinic on Saturday. There is one doctor, who can be contacted via nurse, on-call 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
- At Maribyrnong IDC, one doctor provides two clinics from Monday to Friday, and one doctor is on-call 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
- At Perth IDC, one doctor provides a clinic each Tuesday and one doctor is on-call 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

- At Christmas Island IRPC, people in detention have the same access to medical care as Christmas Island residents, i.e. consultations via Christmas Island Hospital. One doctor is on call 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

item.label: (c)
item.para: Both DIMIA and contracted staff, including psychiatrists and doctors, offer and utilise interpreters whenever necessary. The interpreting needs of DIMIA and its contractors are met in the following manner:

item.label: (i)
item.para: For Farsi/Dari interpreters, as at 30 March 2005, there are three interpreters employed by the Detention Service Provider, GSL. Two interpreters were previously employed by GSL, completing their employment in May 2004 and February 2005 respectively.

item.label: (ii)
item.para: For Pashtun interpreters, telephone interpreting agencies are used.

item.label: (iii)
item.para: For Uzbek interpreters, telephone interpreting agencies are used.

item.label: (iv)
item.para: For Tajik interpreters, telephone interpreting agencies are used.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 March 2005:

item.para: In respect of those people who could not prove their claims for refugee status, how many were able to show discrimination or threat, not amounting to persecution under the Geneva Convention but enough to make them flee their country, that was not substantial enough for them to gain protection in Australia.
How many people had claims of persecution which were not accepted on the basis that the situation had changed since they fled (ie Afghans whose claims were based on persecution by the Taliban).
From which countries did the remaining people originate.
How long did it take to assess these people’s claims for refugee status.
Has the department been developing any further cost effective ways of ensuring that the remaining non-refugees and refugees are identified.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) systems do not record this information in a reportable form.
DIMIA systems do not record this information in a reportable form.
DIMIA systems do not record this information in a reportable form.
DIMIA systems are unable to report on this matter.

The Department constantly reviews the process of assessing applications for further protection to ensure they are processed in the most streamlined, cost-effective and rigorous manner. Australia has one of the most efficient and reliable refugee assessment processes in the world.

The proportion of those claiming refugee protection who are in need of Australia’s protection varies widely according to their particular claims, their nationality, and the human rights situation in their homeland at the time. The major constraint to further reductions in the cost of decision-making are the safeguards in the existing processes to provide individuals with an equitable opportunity to present their case, to receive and comment on any adverse personal information relating to their claims, which might be taken into account by the decision-maker, and to provide applicants with detailed reasons for any refusal decision and opportunities for merits review.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 March 2005:

quote.para: How many people held in Australian detention centres awaiting deportation are currently serving parole in relation to offences committed under federal or state laws.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

quote.para: As at 18 February 2005, there were 973 people in immigration detention. Of these, 45 people were detained as a direct result of criminal activity leading to decisions pursuant to sections 200 and 501 of the Act. Of these people:

item.para: 40 had served sentences in an Australian prison for criminal activity, 12 of whom are currently on parole; and
5 have been detained due to prior criminal convictions outside Australia or are otherwise deemed to be not of good character.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 March 2005:

item.para: How many Iraqi asylum seekers are on (a) expired and (b) soon to expire temporary protection visas.
How many in (1) are awaiting the determination of a claim for continuing protection.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: and (b) Where a Temporary Protection Visa (TPV) holder applies for further protection before the expiry date of their TPV, the TPV status can continue until the application for further protection is finally determined.

This means that the only Iraqi TPV grantees whose TPVs have expired are those who either did not apply for further protection before their TPV expired, or have been finally determined not to be refugees.
As at 25 February 2005, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) records indicate that some 20 Iraqi nationals in Australia have had their TPV status expire.
As at 25 February 2005 some 2850 applications for further protection, from Iraqi TPV grantees whose TPV has reached 30 months from grant date, are still to be decided by the Department.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 March 2005:

item.para: Does the Minister’s department propose to re-assess every individual applicant who applies for permanent protection when their TPV expires.
How many applicants have applied for such protection.
How many applicants have been approved at their first review.
How many applicants have appealed to the Refugee Review Tribunal.
How many applicants have left Australia voluntarily.
How many applicants are awaiting decisions.
What is the estimated cost of assessing each applicant.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Yes. The Department is under a statutory obligation to assess and decide protection visa applications.

The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) records indicate that as at 25 February 2005 some 9,300 applications for further protection have been lodged. Whether any further visa granted is a temporary or permanent visa will depend on a number of factors, including the person’s actions as they travelled to Australia.
DIMIA records indicate that as at 25 February 2005, some 2,500 grants have been made at the primary decision stage on applications for further protection.
DIMIA records indicate that as at 25 February 2005, some 1,500 decisions on applications for further protection have been appealed to the Refugee Review Tribunal.

DIMIA systems show that as at 27 February 2005, some 320 former Temporary Protection Visa (TPV) holders have departed Australia without waiting for resolution of a further protection visa application. Reports on departures of Temporary Humanitarian Visa holders are not currently available.
DIMIA records indicate that as at 25 February 2005, some 4,800 applications for further protection were awaiting a departmental decision at primary stage.
DIMIA financial systems do not allow processing costs of applications for further protection to be disaggregated from the other protection visa processing costs incurred by the Department.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 March 2005:

item.para: What advice has the Minister’s department given to Afghan refugees about the safety of returning to Afghanistan.
What information has the department used to make that assessment and does this include specific information regarding the refugees’ former areas of residence.
What information is there on the situation facing refugees of Hazara ethnicity.
What criteria are officers using to determine claims for permanent protection.
Has the department received assurances that it is safe to return these refugees.
What legal advice has been sought on this matter.
What legal advice has been sought on the view that only the UNHCR has the right to remove refugee protection.
Will the Minister explain the application of the cessation clauses of the Convention in these cases.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Australia does not return anybody who is found to be a refugee to a place of persecution. People who have been found to be refugees are free to leave Australia at any time should they wish to do so and are not obliged to inform the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) of this. DIMIA does not advise clients about safety in returning to their home country. Some 3.5 million Afghan refugees and former refugees have returned to Afghanistan in recent years, many under UNHCR auspices (including some 200,000 Afghans of Hazara ethnicity).

As stated above, DIMIA does not provide advice on safety to return. The Department’s Country Information Service maintains information on provinces and districts of concern within Afghanistan from a wide range of sources.

The Department’s Country Information Service maintains comprehensive information on the human rights and security situations in countries around the world. Afghanistan, including Afghans of the Hazara ethnicity, is a priority for country research. The Country Information Service is in close consultation with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade network of overseas posts as well as the equivalent governmental country research agencies in Europe and North America. There is also close consultation with non-government and inter-governmental organisations (dealing with human rights concerns) and individual country experts, as well as extensive and continuous monitoring of academic, media and Internet information sources.

A decision-maker must be satisfied that the applicant has met all legislative requirements for grant of a permanent protection visa. One of these requirements is that the decision-maker is satisfied that the applicant is owed protection obligations under the Refugees Convention. In reaching their conclusion the decision-maker considers whether the applicant has a well-founded fear of persecution for a Convention reason at the time of decision.
Australia does not return anybody who is found to be a refugee.

The Australian Government has not sought such assurances. The most effective way to ensure that persons do not suffer persecution if returned to their homeland is to have a robust process to identify refugees and protect them so that they are not returned. Australia has such a process which includes access to merits review by an independent tribunal of any unsuccessful protection claim. Applicants who are unsuccessful at the tribunal level have access to judicial review by the courts. Their cases are closely and regularly monitored to identify any instances in which the Ministerial intervention powers may be appropriately used to either to allow a fresh protection visa application to be lodged or to grant a visa on non refugee grounds. This process allows consideration of claims that may raise Australia’s protection obligations under other international human rights instruments to which Australia is a party. The persons returned have been conclusively found not to face any well founded fear of persecution. To date there have been no involuntary returns to Afghanistan.
The Department has not sought legal advice on this matter.

The Refugees Convention does not in any way provide that the cessation clauses can only be applied by the UNHCR, or that only UNHCR can remove refugee protection. The interpretation and obligations under the Refugees Convention is a matter for State parties to the Convention.

Where an application for a further protection visa has been made, it is necessary for decision-makers to be satisfied afresh that the applicant has a well-founded fear of persecution for a convention reason. This assessment includes an assessment of whether the cessation clauses of the Convention apply to all of the claims made by the applicant, at the time of decision. To date, the courts have agreed with the Department’s approach to assessment. The Department has been successful in all eight matters involving applicants for further protection which have proceeded to final court hearing and judgment.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 March 2005:

item.para: What is the cost of the reprocessing of Temporary Protection Visa (TPV) claims.
Have additional staff been engaged to reprocess TPV claims; if not, would the staff reprocessing TPV claims otherwise have been reallocated to other duties.
How many Afghan asylum seekers have returned since the reintegration package for Afghan refugees was announced on 16 December 2002.
What follow-up has been done to ensure the safety and wellbeing of these people.
Have departmental officers carried out follow-up visits; if so, when.
Has a report been commissioned to consider the re-settlement conditions and wellbeing of these people.

Can the Minister say how many Afghan returnees under the Government’s reintegration package have left Afghanistan for a neighbouring country; if so, (a) to which countries did they go and (b) is the Australian Government aware of the reasons why they are moving.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: DIMIA financial systems do not allow processing costs of applications for further protection to be disaggregated from the other protection visas processing costs incurred by the Department.

Staffing resources have been progressively adjusted to match ongoing community caseloads as well as further protection caseloads, drawing on existing Departmental resources and recruitment as necessary.
Sixty seven failed Afghan asylum seekers have returned to Afghanistan since 16 December 2002.

The Department does not monitor returnees. Australia has effective processes to protect refugees so they are not sent home in the first place. The people in question have had access to that process and were found not to need protection. Australia does not return anybody who is found to be a refugee to a place of persecution. People who have been found to be refugees are free to leave Australia at any time should they wish to do so and are not obliged to inform the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) of this. DIMIA does not advise clients about safety in returning to their home country. Some 3.5 million Afghan refugees and former refugees have returned to Afghanistan in recent years, many under UNHCR auspices (including some 200,000 Afghans of Hazara ethnicity).
No.
No.
No. It is not known how many, if any, Afghan returnees have left Afghanistan for a neighbouring country. (a) This is not known. (b) No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, in writing, on 10 March 2005:

item.para: With respect to the construction of the Darwin to Alice Springs Railway, what was the (a) full cost of construction and (b) current contribution by each investor including the Australian, South Australian and Northern Territory Governments?

In considering the initial decision to invest in the railway and subsequent additional contributions, (a) what projections were made in the business case for the carriage of (i) passengers, (ii) domestic freight, and (iii) international freight and (b) what has been achieved by the railway to date for the carriage of (i) passengers, (ii) domestic freight, and (iii) international freight since the opening of the railway?

Have any consultations occurred between the operator of the railway and the Commonwealth and the South Australian or Northern Territory Governments concerning potential additional financial contributions relating to the operation of the railway?

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr Anderson

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: $1.3 billion.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The Australian and Northern Territory Governments are each contributing up to $191.4 million and the South Australian Government is contributing up to $176.4 million. The remaining $740.2 million was funded by the private Asia Pacific Transport Consortium.

(2) (a) The Australian Government’s decision to contribute funds to the project was not based on any one particular feasibility study but on the significant benefits that the rail link would provide to the Northern Territory, South Australia and the entire nation.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The Great Southern Railway, operator of the passenger service on the Adelaide to Darwin Railway, reported that in its first year of service The Ghan carried over 70,000 passengers.

FreightLink, operator of the freight services on the Adelaide to Darwin Railway, reported that nearly 600,000 tonnes of freight were carried in its first 12 months, some 220,000 tonnes above its first year target of 380,000 tonnes.
FreightLink, operator of the freight services on the Adelaide to Darwin Railway, reported that more than 16,000 tonnes of freight were exported via the Port of Darwin.

item.label: (a)
item.para: The Australian Government’s decision to contribute funds to the project was not based on any one particular feasibility study but on the significant benefits that the rail link would provide to the Northern Territory, South Australia and the entire nation.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The Great Southern Railway, operator of the passenger service on the Adelaide to Darwin Railway, reported that in its first year of service The Ghan carried over 70,000 passengers.

FreightLink, operator of the freight services on the Adelaide to Darwin Railway, reported that nearly 600,000 tonnes of freight were carried in its first 12 months, some 220,000 tonnes above its first year target of 380,000 tonnes.
FreightLink, operator of the freight services on the Adelaide to Darwin Railway, reported that more than 16,000 tonnes of freight were exported via the Port of Darwin.
The Australian Government has had no consultations with the operator of the railway concerning potential additional financial contributions relating to the operations of the railway.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 10 March 2005:

item.para: What was the nature of the selection or tender process used to appoint the former Justice, Mr Street, to advise the Government on priority issues related to the tender process for defence ship construction.
What was the nature of the consultation between the Government and Mr Street leading to this engagement.
Who initiated the contract and who was involved in consultations relating to his engagement.

In respect of Mr Street’s consultancy, (a) what is its duration, (b) from which location will he work, and (c) is there a statement of the duties he is to carry out; if so, (i) what is it, (ii) when was it agreed, and (iii) what is the contracted cost of office accommodation and secretarial support for the duration of the contract.

What are the terms of, and conditions of payment for, Mr Street’s consultancy (including superannuation payments, travel entitlements, salary and whether he will be paid in the form of salary or whether fees will be paid to a company structure).

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: The Secretary, Department of Defence, chose Sir Laurence Street based upon his proven competency and expertise in this line of work. The Secretary considered alternatives before making his decision, and judged that Sir Laurence’s experience in this area fitted him best for the task.
The only consultation with Sir Laurence Street was conducted by the Secretary, Department of Defence, and Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Defence Materiel Organisation.
The contract was initiated by the Secretary, Department of Defence. The Secretary consulted with the Deputy Chief Executive Officer and General Counsel, Defence Materiel Organisation.
(4) (a) 400 hours. This may be extended by mutual agreement.

item.label: (a)
item.para: 400 hours. This may be extended by mutual agreement.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Meetings and conferences will be attended principally in both Sydney and Canberra.

item.label: (c)
item.para: Yes.

item.label: (i)
item.para: To act as an independent adviser to the Department of Defence, Defence Materiel Organisation, for the Air Warfare Destroyer Project, Amphibious Ship Project and sale of ASC activities, providing advice with respect to agency stakeholder governance including process integrity, conflict of interest management and probity review.

item.label: (ii)
item.para: 5 January 2005.

item.label: (iii)
item.para: Nil.

Sir Laurence will be paid per hour plus GST for time spent on the consultancy in attending meetings and conferences, and for time spent on the consultancy in general consideration including reading of documents and research. Time spent on the consultancy shall include time out of the consultant’s office in attending meetings and conferences, but will not include travelling time in attending meetings and conferences in Sydney. Travel expenses will be paid by Defence. Sir Laurence has been engaged as an individual.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 10 March 2005:

item.para: Did the World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control enter into force generally on 27 February 2005.
With which countries has Australia communicated about the Convention since Australia became a party to it on 27 October 2004.
What were the dates, subjects and outcomes of the communications with those countries.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Yes.

Departmental representatives attended the second Open-ended Intergovernmental Working Group (IGWG) on the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) in Geneva from 31 January to 4 February 2005. Delegation members interacted formally and informally with a large number of other delegations. A full list of participants at the meeting is available from the House of Representatives Table Office.

During the period December 2004 to February 2005, the two months leading up to the second session of the Open-ended Intergovernmental Working Group on the FCTC, there were a number of informal communications at Departmental level with New Zealand, Canada and Japan.

Departmental representatives attended a session of the first meeting of the Pacific Senior Health Officials Network on 26 November 2004. The Network meeting was attended by representatives from Fiji, Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, Samoa, Vanuatu, Tonga and Nauru.

The IGWG meeting held in Geneva from 31 January 2005 to 4 February 2005 discussed a number of matters that will be referred to the first FCTC Conference of the Parties (COP), particularly the arrangement for the permanent secretariat and the Rules of Procedure for the COP.

Various models for the secretariat were discussed and several principles agreed, including housing of the secretariat within World Health Organization (WHO) and the need for maximum synergy between the secretariat and other WHO programs, especially the Tobacco Free Initiative, to avoid duplication and ensure value for money. There was agreement that the secretariat arrangements need to be reviewed after two years. Many of the draft Rules of Procedure were agreed but some key issues (status of non-Party country observers, involvement by non-governmental organisations, and procedures for consensus decision making) will need to be further considered by the COP. The IGWG also agreed that the COP should follow the financial rules of the World Health Assembly. The meeting also reviewed the terms of reference for a study of actual and potential sources of financial assistance for the implementation of the FCTC. This will be undertaken by the WHO Tobacco Free Initiative as interim secretariat to the COP. The outcomes of this meeting are expected to be available on the World Health Organization website www.who.int/tobacco/framework.

While the IGWG meeting inevitably focussed on administrative detail, these discussions played an important role in establishing the necessary infrastructure for the COP to begin consideration of substantive tobacco control issues such as product regulation and cross-border advertising.

Informal communications with New Zealand, Canada and Japan during December 2004 and January 2005 included topics such as countries views on the approach to be taken at the upcoming Working Group meeting. These communications provided Australia with an understanding of these countries broad policy position on matters such as the secretariat for the Convention’s Conference of the Parties.

The session of Pacific Senior Health Officials Network meeting attended by Departmental representatives on 26 November 2004 discussed various matters on tobacco including the economic impact of tobacco in the region and the FCTC. There was general understanding that through the Network there would be benefit from future exchanges about tobacco policy issues.

The Pacific Senior Health Officials Network aims to support the Australian Government’s agenda of public sector capacity building by pooling expertise and skills to meet shared health challenges, create linkages between the Department of Health and Ageing and Health Ministries in the Pacific, facilitate communication and provide opportunities to work together and share best practice.

subdebateinfo.title: UNESCO Convention on Technical and Vocational Education

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 10 March 2005:

item.para: With which countries has the Government communicated about the 1989 Unesco Convention on Technical and Vocational Education.
What were the dates, circumstances and results of the communications.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Australia has not signed the 1989 UNESCO Convention on Technical and Vocational Education, and there is no record of formal communications with other countries on this subject.

The Convention was, however, an item of discussion between Australian and other participants at the UNESCO Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) Asia Pacific Conference held in Adelaide over 26-28 March 2001. More than 200 participants representing 37 countries from Asia, the Pacific, Europe and North America attended the Conference, which was co-sponsored by UNESCO, AusAID, the then Commonwealth Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs, the then South Australian Department of Education, Training and Employment and the Australian National Training Authority.
The outcomes of the Conference discussions can be found at:
www2.tafe.sa.edu.au/institutes/adelaide/unevoc/2001conf/summary_report.html

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education, in writing, on 10 March 2005:

item.para: How many first year apprentices, by trade, were employed in the electoral division of Newcastle in (a) 2001, (b) 2002, (c) 2003, and (d) 2004.
How many first year apprentices, by trade, were employed in 1996 in the electoral division of Newcastle.
By what means and by which agency are these statistics collected.
Will he provide (a) the dates and other details of the statistics and (b) the calculations which are used to determine the statistics.

Under the New Apprenticeships Scheme, how many apprentices and trainees were in training, by industry, in the electoral division of Newcastle in the year (a) 1996, (b) 1998, (c) 2000, (d) 2002 and (e) 2004.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
talker.role: Minister for Vocational and Technical Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister
talker.name: Mr Hardgrave

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The National Centre for Vocational Education Research (NCVER) provides estimates of commencements for New Apprenticeships in Trades and Related occupations but does not separate New Apprenticeships estimates by apprentice and trainee. The following table lists New Apprentices with workplaces in the electoral division of Newcastle who commenced a Trades and Related New Apprenticeship in the 12 months to September 2001, 2002, 2003 and 2004: that is the New Apprentice was in their first year in the previous 12 month period. These are the latest estimates available from the NCVER.

item.label: (a)
item.para: Represents figures in the range of 1 to 9
The following table provides NCVER estimates of Trades and Related New Apprenticeships commencements in the 12 months to September 1996 in the electorate of Newcastle.

quote.para: (a) Represents figures in the range of 1 to 9

item.para: These estimates are sourced from the National Centre for Vocational Education Research (NCVER). The NCVER is the body responsible for the collection and dissemination of data relating to the Vocational Education and Training (VET) system in Australia, including New Apprenticeships. The data is collected by the State and Territory Training Authorities (STA) through information provided on the National Training Contract. This data is then provided by each of the STAs to the NCVER.
(4) (a) The data is sourced from the latest collection: NCVER Apprentices and Trainees data for the September Quarter 2004.

item.label: (a)
item.para: The data is sourced from the latest collection: NCVER Apprentices and Trainees data for the September Quarter 2004.

item.label: (b)
item.para: As the NCVER Apprentices and Trainees data is sourced from a statistical database, an estimation process is applied to the raw data to ensure that the data meets the Australian Vocational Education and Training Management Information Statistical Standard (AVETMISS) for New Apprenticeships. This estimation process applies a complex mathematical formula to the raw data to compensate for time lags in reporting commencements and completions. Further information on the estimation process can be obtained from the NCVER.

Industry as identified in Question 5 is the Australia and New Zealand Standard Industrial Classification (ANZSIC) division of the employer. This classification system is developed and maintained by the Australian Bureau of Statistics.
New Apprentices in-training by ANZSIC Division – Newcastle (source:NCVER)
